clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Scoring Systems for Bleeding in Open Cardiac Surgery Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Preoperative Scoring Systems for Prediction of Perioperative Bleeding in Patients To Be Operated for Open Cardiac Surgery

lead_sponsor.agency: Kocaeli Derince Education and Research Hospital

clinical_study.source: Kocaeli Derince Education and Research Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Seven different scoring systems used for prediction of perioperative bleeding were compared regarding patients operated for elective open cardiac surgery in the investigator's study.

detailed_description.textblock: Collected data of 500 consecutive patients, operated for elective open cardiac surgery were analyzed retrospectively. Seven different scoring systems were used to predict the probability of bleeding, including TRACK, PAPWORTH, WILL-BLEED, CRUSADE, ACTION, TRUST and ACTA-PORT. The scores are calculated for each of these systems by using their own parameters, and classified into four risk groups as very low, low, moderate and high. Then, these risk groups were compared with patients identified in two groups regarding the use of perioeprative erythrocyte suspension (ES) transfusions or not, as ES positive and ES negative.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Bleeding risk scores were calculated through study completion, an average of 2 years.
primary_outcome.description: Bleeding scores were calculated in points ranging from 0 to 4.(0 the lowest and 4 the highest risk score for bleeding)

primary_outcome.time_frame: The amount of blood transfusions were recorded through study completion, an average of 2 years.
primary_outcome.description: The amount of blood transfusions were recorded in units.

intervention.intervention_name: Calculation of scoring systems for bleeding

study_pop.textblock: Patients over 18 years of age who were operated for elective open cardiac surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with 18 years of age or older,
2. Patients operated for elective open cardiac surgery.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with incomplete data,
2. Patients with an age less than 18 years,
3. Patients operated for emergent surgical procedures.
